title: Extracting semantic user networks from informal communication exchances social web

author: Suvodeep Mazumdar, Department of Computer Science, University of Sheffield

segmentation: Hi, my name is Sylvia Masuda.
I'm working in the old group in the Department of Computer Science in University of Sheffield, and there is a bit of background to this talk and initially about a few weeks back with you.
We thought that Anna Lisa would be presenting it.
But then few days back we knew that Vita would be presenting it, and three days back I knew that I would be presenting it and we kind of have a feeling that this talk might be jinxed so.
So maybe the roof I'll fall off.
So anyway, I'm not an expert in information extraction or information retrieval, but I'll try to explain this talk to the best of my knowledge.
So what we're trying to do here?

It is to exploit knowledge that is often buried within an organization and with that knowledge we want to generate semantic profiles and using these profiles we would like to use them in an organizational knowledge management context.
Now before I start, I'd like to explain what I'm.
Mean by informal communication.
By informal communication, we mean that the communication within an organization which is not been archived by the organization and being used by the organization.
These examples include informal emails, meeting requests, meeting records, things we discuss while we meet on the corridor of chats.
Instant messages, but for the context of this talk I would be focusing on emails.
To give an example, what are the kind of emails that we send around that?
Are that we include in this type of communication?
There is an example where people talk about Christmas.
Food people talk about some blogs which might be interesting.
People talk about some call for papers which may be interesting as well.
And what we would ideally want to do is to fire to pick up who sending these emails to whom.

And in addition to that, we want to pick up what are the topics of these emails and using this information we want to build a network of people and build their profiles on the basis of the emails they've sent or been received.
Now how do we do that we?
Receive our approach to be a threefold approach.
Initially we collect the features.
And then we generate user profiles on the basis of that features and then we use these profiles and in in a in an organization and.
So we look at emails that have been sent around and we.
Convert them to user profiles and use these email users user profiles on the basis of.
Visualization systems or browsing systems or information retrieval systems.
So I'll go through each of them and discuss what we what we've looked at from the previous literature so.
When we talk about collecting features from emails, we've looked at some.
We've looked at some literature where people have been looking at exchange frequency.
People have been looking at how people communicate with each with each other within an organization.
They look at things like absolute frequency thresholds.
They look at static profiles.
They look at building static profiles.
People look at building dynamic profile profiles on the basis of time.
Um, people looked.

Have looked at contents of these emails and look at how we can determine expertise or how we can analyze relations between content and people, or how we can extract personal information like name, Age, address, contact and so on.
While generating user profiles, what people have also looked at is by monitoring user activities on the web.
Can we generate user profiles by analyzing tweets or Twitter content?
Can we generate profiles?
And people have been profiling users and bring measuring how similar people are to others about other people and defining them on the basis of binary functions.
Whether I am similar to another person and non binary functions.
So what is the strength of our similarity and the features that are typically exploited?
Our geographical features, location, age, interests, social interests or even Facebook friends, Facebook interactions, likes, pictures and so on that are shared between two people.
And while using this profile, people have been looking at making use of profiles in on the basis of information retrieval.
So can we customize search results and better provide better results to users on the basis of their profiles?
Can we?
Can we customize recommendations or suggestions while people are searching?
So when we gather all of this information together, we want to answer one simple research question that does increasing the level of semantics in user profiles outperform current methods.
So what we want to do is we want to infer similarity among users.
And we want to understand how well this similarity that we automatically infer.
Alliance with human judgment.
Now, in order to do this, we've got to start off by capturing information.

So I'll give a brief demonstration of a video that we've compiled where a user enters a topic of a particular meeting, and this isn't capturing meeting requests, so users mentioned what time they want to meet.
They want to mention what time the meeting is going to end.
They also mention where who is hosting this meeting.
Um, other details.

As in who are going to attend this meeting, I'll just skip through this and just explain while it goes and they also mentioned where they're going to meet, so we have all of this information during generation of this email and.
Once that's done, we add in what is the meeting going to be discussing and and that is then sent off to the back end data store and we we store this information.
Now the other thing that we can do is we can archive emails.
We can collect a lot of emails and then archive them and then upload to our service and add some descripcion at some details to that to the archive so that we don't want content this is.
Or we know the president of this information.
And then we pass it onto background service.
We see that there is some processing involved and then we see in the end that this data has been archived.
Now, once we've done that, we want to look into the experiments that we want to.
We want to conduct, so we've been looking at emails that have been sent to within the Oak Group and these emails have been sent to the entire group.
So to the entire mailing list of the group.
And we've collected this emails over a period of 10 months.
As far as I remember correctly, and we've collected 1001 emails and the total number of users were 40 and the number of active users who have been sending more emails and receiving.
So they have been 20 and the number of users that participated in the evaluation has been 15.
Now what we do is we collect the features from these from these emails and we look at three types of features.
We look at keywords we looked at named entities and we looked at concepts.
So in order to extract features from these emails, we look at a service which is called Java automatic term recognition.
We've looked at open Kelly Web service to provide us with entities, and we've looked at Wiki fight to provide us with context their contents concepts.
And we tried to compare them and we've measured.
We've we've measured similarity between what one person is and what another person.
So we've measured similarity between two persons using the Jaccard index.
And we've done it for all of the different types of information we've collected.
And then we asked users if they what they feel they are sick.

The two, so we've asked participants to to provide their perceived similarity with their colleagues and from a professional and social point of view, and also looking at the points or topics of interest.
So we've asked people to say that, do you think you are similar to this person, and how much similar do you think they are?
So from a scale of 1 to 10, we've asked him, are we similar to this person, and how much are you similar to him?
And and then we looked at how we could evaluate it.
We've considered the 3 three ways of the three collections that we had for keywords, concepts as well as entities, and we've tried to correlate those those numbers that we had with what the users?
And this is the results that we've achieved.
And we tried.
Sum it up by taking an average of it, and we realized that the concepts start to show more significance.
So from what here, what we realized is that users.
Find themselves similar to other users and if we match that with keywords named entities and concepts, we've realized that people find concepts to be a good measure of finding similar users.
Now, how do we use this information?

We look at user profiles and we could we could use this in an organization by looking at emails that people send around, and by looking at retrieving these emails on the basis of user experience or user profiles and we also look at how we can visualize these emails.
In knowledge management perspective.
So we started with a tool that is called simnet.

Similar provides a radiograph of all the users in a particular organization, and it tries to color code the emails that they've been sending to their colleagues by representing the sent mails as Orange mails and receive Mail says Green Mails and when you click on one user you can also find out the tag cloud of all these emails that have been sent.
And you can also browse through these emails by providing dates, so you could see how an hour network changes over a period of time.
And you could also plot the similarity between 2 users by by drawing lines between users.
Now the next thing we focused on was to make use of similarity and make use of expertise within an organization.

So here we show the old group and we show the different kind of expertise that is there in the old group when we click on one of them, we provide all the users who are experts in that particular topic.
Now these have been generated by the extraction system that we've been developing.
And this is a force directed layout approach and this is a radial layout approach.
So what we've thought is first directed layouts can show very well relations among individuals.
They can show very well relations among people in the industry, in the in, the organization, radial layouts are very good at showing enter interactions.
They're very good showing how people have interacted with in this organization.
So the next step was that we wanted to combine both of these approaches to come up with a different kind of visualization.
Which is looking at force directed layouts as well as providing information in a radial graph.
So we've modified the simnet.
Tool and this is an example that I'll be showing you so here.
The two loads up with clusters of everyone in the group and these clusters are based on.
The expertise that we found.
And as you see that when it loads up it, it spreads out everywhere and it uses force directed approach to spread out these clusters.
And each of these clusters are radial visualizations which show interaction within this cluster and also interaction to other groups from other clusters.
The users can freeze notes and move them around as they want.
So that it's easier for them to play around with it, I'll just go back.

Now the interesting thing that we've noticed over here is that all of these people were members of one group, but we see a lot of people from technology in general, so this is a cluster that we used where we couldn't define which group they would be falling into.
So this is a cluster where we've seen that these people interact more with other people and also work on things like social web.
This is a cluster where we've seen people are working on information retrieval.
And this is these are people who've been talking about a lot of politics.
These are people who've been working on a lot of knowledge representation, so building ontologies.

Now when we combine everything together in this exploration tool, we've realized that people do not talk much amongst themselves and people talk to other people, other people from other research areas.
Reaching that, this is because a lot of people collaborate with other people from other research groups or other research areas within one group.
And they send emails among themselves, but they do not around people who've been who've been associated with the same expertise.
And there's another reason why this is possible is because people are people work to tend to work out there to talk to people who are working on the same projects.

So HCR people do not talk too much with amongst themselves, though they have some level of interaction but they talked to a lot of people from technology from social or from information retrieval and that is possibly because they haven't been grouped according to projects.
If we had grouped them according to projects.
You would probably see a lot of Inter cluster intra cluster communication.

So here is an example where the user lays out the network as they want and then the user is searching for a topic which is Twitter and once it does that you can see that the system has highlighted 5 individuals among the network who have talked more about Twitter and over here the user is adding another topic which is human computer interaction.
So this user is looking at people who've been talking a lot about Twitter as well as human computer interaction.
And this system helps pick up the people who've been talking more about it and suggest experts.
Now when you click on one user you get a highlighted list of all the emails that that's been sent around the whole network.
So when you click on that, you get an updated tag cloud.
So this tag cloud combines all of the emails that have been highlighted and gives an overview of what are the emails that have been sent around.
Now we also have access to all these emails that have been shown here.
So once a user.
Clicks on a particular selects a particular topic.
So for example, the user is selecting chocolate and the user sees that there are four people around the network who talked about chocolates.
The user can Scroll down and find a list of all of these emails.
So we are currently in the process of looking at how we can improve this system.
We are showing this around to people and getting their feedback and trying to understand what could be improved from this system.
For example, the freeze nodes.
We've realized that force directed layouts are sometimes not very suited for a lot of people, and in that case they can freeze the nodes and they can move it around as they wish.
So we've basically looked at how we can profile users.
We looked at.

We realized that semantic profiling would be more helpful and would outperform normal profiling on the basis of keywords and named entities, and we've looked at how we can use these profiling in a knowledge management perspective.
So to conclude, dynamically no model users expertise from information communication, informal communication exchanges.
We've generated semantic user profiles from textual content generated by users, and we've made used of Barrett knowledge within an organization.
Now this knowledge would never be used ever and this knowledge can tell us a lot about what people talk about within themselves in the social context, not only about work but also about social.
And.
